title: 106_s2267
content: The "Amateur Sports Integrity Act" and the "Athletic Performance-Enhancing Drugs Research and Detection Act" establish programs for research and detection of performance-enhancing drugs in sports. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will establish a program to support research on performance-enhancing substances used by athletes and methods of detecting their use through grants of financial assistance. The program will focus on banned substances in competitive events sanctioned by organizations like the International Olympic Committee and the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will establish a program to fund research on detecting performance-enhancing substances used by athletes, including steroids, testosterone precursors, human growth hormone, and erythropoietin. Research will focus on ensuring accurate tests for men, women, all age groups, and ethnicities. No research will be funded on drugs of abuse. The Director will establish a program to fund research on detecting performance-enhancing substances used by athletes, including steroids, testosterone precursors, human growth hormone, and erythropoietin. Research will focus on accurate tests for all demographics. The program will not fund research on drugs of abuse like cocaine, phencyclidine, marijuana, morphine/codeine, and methamphetamine/amphetamine. Technical and scientific peer review procedures will be established for grant evaluation, with minimum criteria, preference for labs with drug testing experience, and a minimum grant award of $500,000. The Director will establish a program to fund research on detecting performance-enhancing substances used by athletes, with minimum criteria including publication and research experience in athletic drug testing, direct transference of research findings to lab applications, and certification as a not-for-profit research program. Technical and scientific peer review procedures will be established for evaluating research results funded by grants under the program. The reviewer will provide a copy of the report to the Director within 30 days after the review. $4,000,000 per fiscal year is authorized for the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology for fiscal years 2001-2005. SEC. 103. PREVENTION AND INTERVENTION PROGRAMS. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will develop a grant program for educational substance abuse prevention and intervention programs for high school and college student athletes using performance-enhancing substances. Minimum criteria for applicants include proposing a program based on evaluation with evidence of efficacy and demonstrating a research record in athletic drug use prevention. Minimum grant award is set at $300,000 per recipient. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will provide grant awards of at least $300,000 per recipient for educational substance abuse prevention programs for student athletes. $3,000,000 per fiscal year is authorized for this program for fiscal years 2001-2005. SEC. 201 prohibits gambling on competitive games involving high school and college athletes and the Olympics under the Ted Stevens Olympic and Amateur Sports Act. It is unlawful to sponsor, operate, advertise, or promote gambling on competitive games involving high school and college athletes or the Olympics. The prohibition against gambling on competitive games involving high school and college athletes or the Olympics applies regardless of other permissions. Civil actions to stop violations can be initiated by the Attorney General, educational agencies, colleges, or sports organizations. The term "high school" is defined as "secondary school" in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Secondary Education Act of 1965 defines terms like "college" and "local educational agency" in relation to other education acts. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the Act. The text chunk "220541. Unlawful sports gambling: Olympics; high school and college athletes." is a part of the subchapter III on miscellaneous topics.
